results.title: Brain sex. Episode 3
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Harris, Ann Moir, Cheryl Knapp, Discovery Channel, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Primetime Television, Quality Time TV and Primedia Productions
results.brief_description: The final program in this series looks primarily at the sexual behaviour of men and women, how it differs, and each sex’s perceptions of the opposite sex’s motivation. It also looks at more differences between the female and male brains, particularly in relation to aging, and relationships with the opposite sex.

results.title: Brain sex. Episode 2
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Harris, Ann Moir, Discovery Channel, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Primetime Television, Quality Time TV and Primedia Productions
results.brief_description: This program looks at differences between the two genders, both real and perceived, and the new discoveries by researchers into the brain, which suggest that these differences are due to physical differences in the male and female brain. How much of our behaviour is predetermined and how much can be learnt or modified should perhaps be reassessed in the light of these discoveries, and new attitudes to difference and equality formed.

results.title: Brain sex. Episode 1
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Harris, Discovery Channel, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Primetime Television, Quality Time TV and Primedia Productions
results.brief_description: Our chromosomes are decided at conception, and shortly thereafter hormones start to play their part in determining sex. This program investigates the role that hormones play in determining sex and sexual characteristics, including behaviour patterns. Can hormones change brain structure? Does the brain determine gender related characteristics? The program looks at studies of children who suffer from Turner’s syndrome and CAH syndrome as we attempt to unravel the roles of nature and nurture in patterns of behaviour.

results.title: Brain is the reason
results.brief_description: A backyard barbecue forms the background for a presentation explaining how alcohol affects judgment and reason and why drinking may cause accidents and death.

results.title: Brahms and his music
results.brief_description: Recreates Brahm’s life among scenes closely associated with his development as a composer. These include Vienna, where he reached the height of his career, and the German countryside he loved. Excerpts from the following are included: Sonata No.3 in F for Piano; Symphony No.1; Symphony No.2, and the D Major Violin Concerto.

results.title: Bradman (Captioned)
results.brief_description: In this unique documentary, Sir Donald Bradman provides his first ever extensive interview on camera. His fascinating insights are interspersed with archival film of his major innings. Other highlights include: “Off the field” scenes during his four tours of England, interviews with former test players Bert Oldfield, Bill Brown and Neil Harvey, and a series coverage of his amazing test statistics.

results.title: Brabazon: king of the air
results.brief_description: A report on the building of the giant, eight-engine Brabazon air liner, from its conception as an idea to the time of its flight in Septpember 1949. Commentary by John Mills.

results.title: Boyz'n the hood
results.creator_credit: John Singleton, Steve Nicolaides and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: In the 1980s, spurned on by the success of Spike Lee, young Afro-American directors began to develop scripts and films for the mainstream American movie industry. Previously, black filmmakers in the United States had to work completely outside the system or in the exploitation genres if they wished to work with black actors and black themes. John Singleton’s “Boyz ‘n the Hood” was one of the pioneering works of this new Hollywood cinema. Cuba Gooding Jr. plays a young man who has grown up in the severely economically deprived inner-city ghetto of South Central Los Angeles. He has to decide whether to follow his friends into a life of gang criminality and drug use or whether to leave behind the “hood” and pursue an academic career as his embittered former activist father wants him to (Larry Fishburne). Refusing the exploitative excesses that dehumanise African-American ghetto characters in most action films, “Boyz n’ the Hood” reveals the complexity of growing up in a segregated world in which entrenched unemployment has meant that for young men, only the drug economy provides any chance for success or wealth. Cast also includes Ice Cube.
